awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the basic human motives that drive behavior has been a question of great historical significance in psychology.  Yet, an integrative theory, allowing for different sociocultural and individual factors that might prioritize one kind of motive over another, is still missing.  This project aims to develop a theoretical model of the sociocultural determinants of human motives.  To develop a powerful testbed, with strong broader impacts, the research examines why and how individual actions are motivated in response to environmental challenges. Environmental crises such as pollution or the depletion of natural resources pose some of the greatest collective challenges faced by society today. Responses of individuals to these challenges have critical consequences. By understanding what drives people's actions in this context, progress will be made in addressing a fundamental question about human behavior. The research is expected to have wide impact across a number of scholarly disciplines, with important implications for public policy, education and philanthropy. 

The theory proposes that different sociocultural and individual factors orient people towards more internal and personal reasons or toward more external and social reasons for their actions.  The factors that orient people toward more internal and personal reasons for their actions include individualistic values, high socioeconomic status, and social belonging.  The factors that orient people toward more external and social reasons for their actions include collectivistic values, low socioeconomic status, and social isolation.  The research examines the extent to which environmental beliefs versus perceived environmental norms drive pro-environmental behaviors, and how this differs for people from a wide range of personal experiences and backgrounds. The explanatory role of sense of control and attention allocation is also investigated. The studies use diverse methodologies including a nationally representative study of Americans, a laboratory behavioral study, a longitudinal study of daily environmental behaviors, and a community field experiment at local grocery stores assessing shopping behavior. The new theoretical model can also be used to understand why and how individual actions are motivated in response to a broad range of collective challenges, including widespread infectious disease and the threat of terrorism.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the basic human motives that drive behavior is a core question in psychology. Yet, an integrative theory, allowing for different sociocultural and individual factors that might prioritize one kind of motive over another, has been missing. This research aimed to develop a theoretical model of the sociocultural determinants of human motives, with a particular focus on the motives underlying proenvironmental action. Reflecting the growing need to address environmental issues, research from a wide variety of fields has sought to increase proenvironmental beliefs (such as that human activities are the main causes of global warming) as a means of increasing proenvironmental action. Yet, what drives action has not been examined across a wide range of sociocultural contexts.

This limited focus raises critical scientific and practical questions about how best to facilitate behavioral responses to combat environmental problems. The sociocultural perspective developed in the present research posits that the primary motives driving action are context dependent. Building on this perspective, research conducted during this grant period has now identified significant divergence in the key determinants of proenvironmental action, focusing on several sociocultural variables and individual factors, including cultural values (individualism-collectivism), socioeconomic status, and social isolation.

The theory proposes that different sociocultural and individual factors orient people towards more internal and personal reasons or toward more external and social reasons for their actions. Several investigations tested the theoretical model, examining these sociocultural and individual factors in isolation, and interactively, and whether there was a common psychological mediator across these factors – a sense of personal control.

Research using a large national sample examined the extent to which environmental support (i.e., proenvironmental behaviors and policy support) was driven by people’s beliefs about the environment as a function of their collectivism and socioeconomic status. The environmental actions of those who were low in collectivism were more likely to be driven by their beliefs than those who were high in collectivism. Similarly, the environmental actions of those higher in socioeconomic status (SES) were more likely to be driven by their environmental beliefs than those lower in SES. Additional research examined when beliefs predict people’s actual engagement in pro-environmental actions, focusing on individuals’ willingness to volunteer time for the environment and consumers’ pro-environmental shopping decisions. Once again, the environmental actions of those higher in SES were more likely to be driven by their beliefs.

What links socioeconomic status and collectivism conceptually is an orientation towards the self (among those higher SES or lower in collectivism) vs. an orientation towards others (among those lower SES, or higher on collectivism). An investigation of the impact of social isolation and loneliness directly examined this self vs. other orientation, reasoning that when people experience loneliness or social isolation they will be more oriented towards others, and hence their beliefs will be less predictive of their environmental actions. Across correlational and experimental studies, people who experience social isolation and loneliness had weaker associations between their environmental beliefs and environmental actions than people who were more socially connected and less lonely.

In addition to examining how these different sociocultural and personal factors influence the relationship between beliefs and environmental action, the research identified an underlying psychological factor to explain these relationships— a sense of personal control. Across these different investigations, those who had higher SES, were less collectivistic, and were less socially isolated generally had a higher sense of personal control. Consistently, a higher sense of personal control was associated with individual beliefs more strongly driving action. Thus, a common psychological mediator was identified across different aspects of human experience that helps understand what drives action.

This general theory has implications for a wide range of fields, including social psychology, political science, communications, and environmental studies, that focus on the antecedents of human behavior. Researchers and practitioners working in these fields have noted an urgent need to understand social, cultural, and demographic diversity in the drivers of environmental action. Addressing this need can yield benefits both for science and for application. For science, this research underscores the importance of examining sociocultural factors, independently and interactively, and identifying underlying psychological processes that can link disparate influences. For application, to the extent that beliefs are malleable, it suggests what groups have the largest potential gain from intervention as well as factors that make it more likely for people to transform their beliefs into meaningful action.
